results:
I found several valuable Polish academic sources and research on Bulgakov's "The Master and Margarita" (Polish: "Mistrz i Małgorzata") in translation studies and literary criticism. Here are the key findings:

## Academic Sources and Research

A scholarly work from the Jagiellonian University analyzes English and Polish translations of Mikhail Bulgakov's novel The Master and Margarita based on A. Berman's set of translatorial deformations. The main aspects discussed include foreignizing and naturalizing tendencies, stylistic amendments, clarification, differences stemming from source text editions, the form and the purpose of footnotes, translations of culturally-specific items and the melodiousness of the language.(no content)The journal "Przekładaniec" published research on translation criticism in cyberspace, noting that digitization and competition between publishing houses has led to "synchronic explosion" of parallel texts, with the newest retranslations of Mikhail Bulgakov's The Master and Margarita being one of the most interesting examples. In recent years, new Polish versions of this novel have been published at a dizzying pace (five new translations between 2015 and 2018).

## Key Polish Academic Publications

The search revealed several Polish academic publications and researchers:

Mistrz i Małgorzata Michaiła Bułhakowa w nowym tłumaczeniu na język polski", Przekłady Literatur Słowiańskich vol. 9, part 1, pp. 267–281.(no content)Przebinda, Grzegorz. 2019. "Mogarycz i inni. Dramatyczne losy kanonu tekstowego Mistrza i Małgorzaty", Przegląd Rusycystyczny 3(167), pp. 36–90.(no content)The same author also published: "Sto dwadzieścia jedna Małgorzata". O tekście pierwszego polskiego przekładu Mistrza i Małgorzaty", Przegląd Rusycystyczny 2(158), pp. 54–79.(no content)Sadowska, Monika. 2018. "Elementy trzeciej kultury w przekładach polskich wersji Mistrza i Małgorzaty Michaiła Bułhakowa", Acta Polono-Ruthenica XXIII/3, pp. 141–155.

## Stylistic Analysis

Polish academic research on the stylistics of Bulgakov's novel indicates that while the literary style is often referred to as satire, parody and grotesque, the novel cannot be called a comic one, since its ideological essence belongs to tragedy. The style takes on a triple model, which is subject to speech style of the characters and narrative.

The search reveals a rich body of Polish academic work on Bulgakov's masterpiece, particularly focusing on translation studies, comparative analysis of different Polish versions, and stylistic analysis within Polish literary criticism.
